t: “As*p for you, take up a lament for the princes of Israel,
and say: What*pn was your mother? A lioness! She*ln lay down among the lions; she*ln reared her cubs among the young lions.
She*ln brought up one of her cubs, and*ln he became a young lion. After*ln he learned to tear prey, he*ln devoured people.
When*ln the nations heard about him, he*ln was caught in their pit. Then*ln they led him away with hooks to*ln the land of Egypt.
When*pn she saw that she waited in vain, that*ln her hope was lost, she*ln took another of her cubs and*ln made him a young lion.
He*ln prowled among the lions, and*ln he became a young lion. After*ln he learned to tear prey, he*ln devoured people.
He*ln devastated their strongholds and*ln destroyed their cities. The*ln land and everything in it shuddered at*ln the sound of his roaring.
Then*ln the nations from the surrounding provinces set*ln out against him. They*ln spread their net over him; he*ln was caught in their pit.
They*ln put a wooden yoke on him with hooks and*ln led him away to the king of Babylon. They*ln brought him into the fortresses so*ln his roar could no longer be heard on*ln the mountains of Israel.
Your*pn mother was like a vine in your vineyard, planted*ln by the water; it*ln was fruitful and full of branches because*ln of abundant water.
It*ln had strong branches, fit for the scepters of rulers; its*ln height towered among the clouds. So*ln it was conspicuous for its height as*ln well as its many branches.
But*ln it was uprooted in fury, thrown*ln to the ground, and*ln the east wind dried up its fruit. Its*ln strong branches were torn off and dried up; fire*ln consumed them.
Now*ln it is planted in the wilderness, in*ln a dry and thirsty land.
Fire*ln has gone out from its main branch and*ln has devoured its fruit, so*ln that it no longer has a strong branch, a*ln scepter for ruling. This*p is a lament and should be used as a lament.”
